items.title: Together a Century, City and Oil Giant Hit a Rough Patch
items.abstract: Chevron has spent millions in recent years trying to shore up its relationship with Richmond, Calif., but many residents still oppose the company’s efforts to repair a refinery hit by a fire.

items.title: ‘Mexsicko City’ Turns a Corner in Its Clean Air Marathon
items.abstract: Even amid other environmental gains, it is the improvement in air quality that has most burnished the city’s green credentials.

items.title: Charting a Post-Pollution Path for Cities – From London, 1952, through Beijing, 2013
items.abstract: Facing epic smog, China charts a shift from coal to gas for Beijing, and beyond.

items.title: Cities Weigh Taking Over From Private Utilities
items.abstract: Municipalities are showing an interest in creating their own utilities, reflecting concerns about climate change and responses to power disruptions.

items.title: Scientists Propose a New Architecture for Sustainable Development
items.abstract: Analysts of global environmental trends seek to topple the three pillars of sustainable development.

items.title: New Study Finds Persistent Peril from Urban Coal Soot in China and Indoor Smoke in India
items.abstract: In Chinese cities and India’s rural households, millions remain at risk from power plant pollution and smoky cooking and heating fires.

items.title: Toxic Moss in Portland, Ore., Shakes City’s Green Ideals
items.abstract: When a study found toxic materials on tree trunks in residential neighborhoods of Portland, it produced an upheaval of surprise, anger and fear.

items.title: Challenging Washington’s Architectural History
items.abstract: Architectural diversity on Washington's National Mall is in full flower.

items.title: Climate Model Predicts West Antarctic Ice Sheet Could Melt Rapidly
items.abstract: The computer program, which accurately modeled past sea levels for the first time, predicts up to three feet of sea level rise from Antarctica by 2100.

items.title: The Deadly Problem of Urban Air Pollution
items.abstract: A new report paints a disturbing picture of the air quality in cities around the world.

items.title: Are Electric Cars Only for the Rich? Sacramento Is Challenging That Notion
items.abstract: With funding from a surprising source, Volkswagen, California is making sure low-income communities have the chance to gain access to electric vehicles.

items.title: South Asia Is Smothered in Toxic Air, Report Finds
items.abstract: A global study from Greenpeace and a software company found that India, Bangladesh and Pakistan had the most polluted air.

items.title: Copenhagen Wants to Show How Cities Can Fight Climate Change
items.abstract: The Danish capital wants to be carbon neutral six years from now. Its plan involves wind, recycling and a very innovative ski hill.

items.title: Want to Escape Global Warming? These Cities Promise Cool Relief
items.abstract: While climate change affects everywhere, some areas in America will be less affected than others. And some of those fortunate places, it happens, might be looking for people.

items.title: Big Buildings Hurt the Climate. New York City Hopes to Change That.
items.abstract: To fight climate change, the city is forcing the buildings, like the Empire State Building and Trump Tower, to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

items.title: America’s Most Energy Efficient Cities
items.abstract: A new report by the American Council for an Energy-Efficient Economy can help you gauge just how green your city is — or wants to be.

items.title: A California City Is Overrun by Crows. Could a Laser Be the Answer?
items.abstract: In a move befitting its Silicon Valley setting, the city of Sunnyvale, Calif., will aim a laser at 1,000 birds that have overwhelmed the downtown area during the pandemic.
keywords: Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)

items.title: A Mayor and the Challenge of Making the City Safer
items.abstract: Eric Adams made public safety a campaign issue. Now, as mayor, he will be held accountable.

items.title: Eric Adams Is Pushing a Plan to Speed Up Buses. Will It Work?
items.abstract: Mayor Eric Adams has promised 150 miles of new bus lanes in New York City, but some drivers and businesses say they have created headaches in the past.

items.title: New York Was Set to Expand Composting. Now It’s on the Chopping Block.
items.abstract: Mayor Eric Adams wants to suspend the expansion of New York’s composting program, but experts say the program is crucial to the city’s climate targets.
